description.narrative: Programme of Support for Deepening Democracy in Indonesia

Establishment of the Indonesian Democracy Index (IDI), an inclusive and consultative framework for the systematic assessment and monitoring of democratic governance goals expressed in Indonesia's national and regional development plans.
capital of a political entity
Elections - elections

comment.narrative:
1) 2007 and 2009 IDI have developed. The Government of Indonesia targeted to publish the index in yearly basis. 2) Besides producing the Indonesia Democracy Index, the Project Management Unit is also planning a programme to capacitating the local governments, through the Provincial Working Groups, to utilize the index for their evidence-based political annual programme development 3) Government of Indonesia has allocated some state budget to develop the Indonesia Democracy Index. There are some approaches to Ministry of Home Affairs to also allocate some funds to the establishment the Provincial Working Groups
New Baseline (2014) : 1) Five indexes have been produced by the project to date: - In 2011, 1 index were produced (2009) - In 2012, 1 index were produced (2010) - In 2013, 1 index were produced (2011) - In 2014, 2 indexes were produced (2012 & 2013) 2) During 2011-2014, IDI results were disseminated at the national level, and within various targeted provinces: - In 2011, IDI results were disseminated to three provinces (i.e. Aceh, Banten, and Gorontalo) - In 2012, IDI results were disseminated to three other provinces (i.e. Bali, West Kalimantan, and North Sulawesi). - In 2013, IDI results were disseminated to 14 provinces (i.e. Bengkulu, Lampung, Bangka Belitung, DKI Jakarta, West Java, Central Java, Yogyakarta, East Java, West Nusa Tenggara, East Nusa Tenggara, Central Kalimantan, South Kalimantan, South Sulawesi, and South-East Sulawesi). - In 2014, IDI results were disseminated to three provinces (i.e. Bangka Belitung, Central Java, and East Nusa Tenggara). - In 2014, IDI results were disseminated to 800 people at the national level through various communication media (i.e. launching event of 2014 IDI score by BPS, live streaming by 34 provinces, 2014 IDI socialization by Kemenko Polhukam). Within Nusa Tenggara, Bangka Belitung and Central Java specifically (the same three provinces targeted for support in 2014 and 2015), IDI results were also di

1) Two 2013 IDI reports published (1 in bahasa Indonesia and 1 in English) and 2014 IDI score released 2) IDI results disseminated to 1 million people through various communication media at the national level, in three targeted provinces (i.e. East Nusa Tenggara, Bangka Belitung, Central Java) and three targeted districts 3) IDI results reflected in 1 planning, budgeting or policy document in each of the three selected provinces (East Nusa Tenggara, Bangka Belitung, Central Java)

2) A set of operational guidelines was identified as important to detail certain section of the RRG
3) BNPB's training institution has not yet developed specific training modules on RRG; BNPB's training institutions has not yet developed specific training modules on RRG

description.narrative: Institutional systems strengthened and established that support disaster risk reduction (DRR) based recovery (rehabilitation and reconstruction)
populated place
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1) Number of and effectiveness of recovery (rehabilitation and reconstruction) partnership and coordination mechanisms among GoI agencies, CSOs, public and private sector organizations and local communities.
2) Extent to which the process of strengthening the GoI’s institutional system for rehabilitation and reconstruction has been documented and made available throughout Indonesia, and at the regional and global levels.

comment.narrative:
1) Existence of a recovery partnership and coordination mechanism as guided by the RRG 2010, which includes the enactment and implantation of a comprehensive post-disaster, needs assessment guideline in 2011, i.e., Indonesia Post Disaster Needs Assessment (I-PDNA). The existence of the platform for facilitating and financing expedited disaster recovery response involving international community was established in 2011 i.e., the Multi Donor Fund Facility for Disaster Recovery (IMDFFDR); and existence of UNDP Surge mechanism to support GoI in ensuring early recovery needs and interventions to take place immediately after a disaster.
2) Lessons learned in the context of post disaster recovery coordination and programming mechanism has not yet been fully documented

1. The roles and responsibilities of multi-stakeholders are prescribed
2. GoI’s recovery financing scheme formulated
3. Documentation and reporting system of IDF Secretariat are operational

The prodoc has been signed in April but the funding has not yet been disbursed from MPTF (Multi Partner Trust Fund) office at HQ thus this initiative is not yet operational - Latest update from Q2 2015

description.narrative: Field application of disaster risk reduction (DRR) based recovery (rehabilitation and reconstruction) practices, methodologies, guidelines and tools with feedback mechanism to policy framework
second-order administrative division

comment.narrative:
1. Further development of system that supports recovery monitoring: - Agreement on survey indicators are reached with BPS and BNPB - Survey methodology and DRI tested in Sinabung and Kelud further refined - Agreement reached on survey methodology and
2. Lessons learned in the context of comprehensive recovery needs assessment documented and disseminated by end of 2015.

1. Inputs from consultants have been provided and a FGD was held on the 9th of March. At present the BNPB, DR4,and technical experts are in process of reviewing the baseline data, indicators and survey methodology.
2. The process of DRI development is ongoing and it is too early to start creating KM or Lesson learnt documents at this stage.

description.narrative: Improved livelihoods of communities affected by the Mount Kelud eruption
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. The extent to which local BPPDs in East Java is strengthened and able to undertake PDNA and recovery coordination with minimal external support.
2. The availability of PDNAs, combining data/information on damages/losses as well as human recovery needs.
3. The availability of local RENAKSI(s), including its implementation guidelines, to guide recovery processes in East Java.
4. The extent to which direct recovery response has addressed the selected most priority needs in the scope of governance, livelihoods, community infrastructure, debris clearance and management, environment, risk reduction, and social cohesion, which are gender sensitive.
5. The existence of DRR mainstreaming strategies for East Java to guide the recovery processes in the respective local regions.

comment.narrative:
1. The capacity of local BPBDs in East Java regions to undertake PDNA and recovery coordination is limited.
2. PDNA as the combined results of HRNA dan DALA for Kelud is completed. HRNA for Sinabung is completed but PDNA not yet finalized due to pending DaLA results
3. RENAKSI for Mount Kelud is not yet finalized and enacted.
4. Limited understanding of local governments in East Java on early recovery as a way to set up the path or create enabling environment for rehabilitation and reconstruction phase.
5. Unavailability of Disaster Management Plan in East Java

1. 5 number of coordination meetings undertaken at district & provincial level in the areas of RENAKSI, RR implementation and RR M&E
2. Process of developing RENAKSIs for Kelud is supported and accomplished in Q2 2015;
3. Recommendations proposed & issues identified for sector-based RR implementation
4. Periodic reassessment of needs and progress of disaster recovery undertaken (field testing LS & social audit)
5. DM plans developed for 3 districts affected by Kelud eruption
6. 35 contingency plans developed in collaboration with village & district govt
7. VIS and Sister-Village approach replicated in 6 villages affected by Mt. Kelud eruption

1. 4 coordination meetings undertaken at district & provincial level in the areas of RENAKSI, RR implementation and RR M&E
2. RENAKSI finalization processses facilitated and final draft has been produced. Pending for formal enactment by BNPB
3. Proposed recommendations to integrate recovery needs with local development initiatives and formulation of Regular RR proposal for funding assistance from BNPB in anticipation of Renaksi absence.
4. DM plans developed for 3 districts affected by Kelud eruption
5. 35 village contingency plans developed in collaboration with village & 3 District Government.

description.narrative: Communities affected by the 2013-2014 Mt Sinabung eruption
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. The extent to which local BPPDs in North Sumatra are strengthened and able to undertake PDNA and recovery coordination with minimal external support.
2. The availability of PDNAs, combining data/information on damages/losses as well as human recovery needs.
3. The availability of local RENAKSI(s), including its implementation guidelines, to guide recovery processes in North Sumatra.
4. The extent to which direct recovery response has addressed the selected most priority needs in the scope of governance, livelihoods, community infrastructure, debris clearance and management, environment, risk reduction, and social cohesion, which are gender sensitive.
5. The existence of DRR mainstreaming strategies for North Sumatra to guide the recovery processes in the respective local regions.

comment.narrative:
1. The capacity of local BPBDs in North Sumatra and East Java regions to undertake PDNA and recovery coordination is limited.
2. PDNA as the combined results of HRNA dan DALA for Kelud is completed. HRNA for Sinabung is completed but PDNA not yet finalized due to pending DaLA results
3. RENAKSIs for Mount Kelud and Mount Sinabung are not yet finalized and enacted.
4. Limited understanding of local governments in East Java and North Sumatra on early recovery as a way to set up the path or create enabling environment for rehabilitation and reconstruction phase.
5. Unavailability of Disaster Management Plan in East Java and North Sumatra.

1. Continue providing support to local government agencies tin coordinating recovery programmes implementation preparatory work in general.
2. The continued eruption of Mt. Sinabung and partial substantive content of PDNA that only included 7 relocated villages. The remaining 25 affected villages have not been assessed for PDNA.
3. Support provided to formulate Renaksi draft but the finalization of Renkasi has been delayed.
4.The recovery situation on the ground is constantly changing as the eruption is not yet settling down and the obscurity of Renaksi document status resulted in the delayed implementation of RR programme.

populated place

By the end of the project at least 435 government staff have been trained and certified in the use of CBFWM approaches. 2.2. description.narrative: Provincial Governance Strengthening Programme (PGSP) : aim to enhance policy and regulatory framework that further clarifies and strengthens roles and functions of Provincial Government and council.

2) RPJMN 2010-2014 contains role and function of provincial government
3) Necessary implementing regulations for revised Law 32 in place

comment.narrative:
1) Distinction between devolved, de-concentrated and assistance functions of provincial government is unclear and often ignored by sector agencies.
2) Overlap between provincial and other levels unresolved.
3) Law 32 is being revised and the relevant implementing regulations at national level are to be aligned with the revised Law 32.
4) Law 32 is being revised and the relevant provincial and local legislations are to be aligned with the revised Law 32.
1) Two policy papers on DLG published 2) Project is properly closed 3) Project report is submitted to the donor 4) Asset transfer is properly addressed

title.narrative: Wind Hybrid Power Generation Market Development Initiatives (WHyPGen)
Wind Hybrid Power Generation (WHyPGen) Market Dev

description.narrative: This project aims to promote the adoption of Wind Hybrid Power Generation (WHyPGen) technology through the facilitation of commercial on-grid WHyPGen systems for on-grid power supply within the Indonesian market.
Energy - power generation

Component 1: • Number of assessed locations with wind power generation potentials by EOP • Number of evaluated existing wind energy systems by EOP • Number of local equipment manufacturers that can potentially produce wind energy (including WHyPGen) system components by EOP
Component 2: • Cumulative electricity production from successfully implemented 2MW WHyPGen pilots/demos by EOP, GWh • Number of WHyPGen projects implemented by EOP (including pilot/demo projects)
Component 3: • Number of completed capacity building programs for banks/FI by EOP • Number of wind energy projects planned with approved financing scheme by EOP
Component 4: • Number of existing WHyPGen-related policies evaluated by EOP • Number of formulated policies (fiscal, market, regulatory, institutional) that are supportive of wind power generation (including WHyPGen) initiatives by EOP
Component 5: • An operational and widely used central database system on wind energy by Year 2
Component 6: • A fully established and operational wind energy clearing house by Year 2

comment.narrative: All baseline for all components are 0

Component 1 : Enhanced knowledge of potential WHyPGen application, Improved knowledge of WhyPGen system benefits, and costs, Enhanced interest in investing in WhyPGen system projects
Component 2 : Increased number of WHyPGen projects planned and implemented, Increased share of wind energy in the national power generation mix
Component 3 : Increased investments on wind power generation (including) WHyPGen projects, Local Banks/financing institutions providing loans for wind power generation (including WHyPGen) projects
Component 4 : Approved and enforced policies supportive of wind power generation projects,
Component 5 : Enhance awareness of the benefits of WHyPGen, Planned and implemented WHyPGen projects
Component 6 : Improved local wind energy system (including WHyPGen) capacity, Ensured availability of local service providers for wind power generation facilities, Availability of quality components of wind energy systems that are locally made, Better understanding of the availability and potentials for wind energy for ensuring environmentally sustainable power supply in Indonesia

Component 1 : Wind Resources Assessment reports and covered 3 new provinces, 6 locations had been identified and reported to have good wind energy resources, 3 evaluation reports on existing wind hybrid power generation
Component 2 : 1 pilot project for wind hybrid power generation in Baron Techno Park, 1 signed PPA for a commercial scale of wind farm project (50MW), 4 wind farm project plans for implementation at several sites, 1 Detail Engineering Design (DED) of wind hybrid power generation was developed by a local service provider company, 1 design on hybrid control system in Nusa Penida
Component 3 : 2 wind farm financial feasibility studies are completed and ready to be used as a proposal for project financing, 1 Completed training on the wind farm project proposal evaluation (technical and economical) for PLN and PLN Pusenlis (30 participants)
Component 4 : 1 capacity building program for the local and central government on the wind farm project development process and the required permits, 5 local companies engage in the wind energy business as project developers and technical service providers
Component 5 : 8 completed promotion tools on wind energy potential and WHyPGen Project, 1 exhibition participation in the Indo-EBTKE connex (national event for renewables energy held by DJEBTKE-MEMR) , 1 video profile and 1 video on “pole to paris” programs , 1 event on the “wind industry day”, 7 local companies become the formatur and member of the Indonesia Wind Energy Association (IWEA)
Component 6 : 35 people (consist of engineers, operators, staff and students) from 10 institutions trained on the wind technology and manufacture process, 30 people from PLN and PLN Pusenlis trained on the wind farm proposal evaluation (technical and economic aspects), 15 trainers from P4TKBMTI involved in the ToT and OJT programs on wind power technology

description.narrative: Number of local banks/FIs that provide affordable financing schemes for WHyPGen projects by EOP

comment.narrative:
1
WHyPGen project through UNDP Indonesia had signed an agreement with PT. SMI in initiating the financing program for wind power project in Indonesia. WHyPGen had allocated USD 300,000 as grant facility to support the bankability of the wind power projects. PT. SMI will leverage the amount up to 10 times. This collaboration is very strategic to ensure the commercial sustainability of investment in the WHyPGen Technology by the project developers. This program is the first financing facility available for wind projects in the country.

Approved and enforced policies supportive of wind power generation projects
Number of formulated policies (fiscal, market, regulatory, institutional) that are supportive of wind power generation (including WHyPGen) initiatives by EOP

comment.narrative:
4 formulated policies :
1. Draft policy on wind power Feed-in Tariff (FIT)
2. Draft National standard on Design requirements for small wind turbines IEC-61400-2 (Persyaratan Rancangan Turbin Angin Skala Kecil)
3. Draft National Standard on Power Performance measurements of electricity producing wind turbines IEC-61400-12-1 (Pengukuran unjuk kerja daya lisrik yang dihasilkan oleh turbin angina)
4. Draft national standard on Measurement and assessment of Power quality characteristic of connected wind turbines IEC -61400-21 (Pengukuran dan pengkajian karakteristik kualitas daya pada koneksi ke grid turbin angin)
To support the formulation of wind project permitting process, the project conducted a capacity building program that involved local governments that has potential wind energy in their region. The activity was mainly to give better understanding on the wind project development process and stages. It is expected that through this program, the central government and the local government will have equal understanding on their role and involvement in the process. Furthermore, the result of the program can also serve as an input in formulating a detail regulation on the permitting process of wind project, especially for a large scale wind farm.

description.narrative: Number of engineering schools that offer courses on wind energy technologies (including WHyPGen applications) in their engineering curricula by EOP

comment.narrative:
5 engineering school had identified applying the RE/Wind hybrid curricula, and make the program to improve the curricula.
1. Sekolah Tinggi Teknik (STT) PLN
2. Universitas Indonesia (UI)
3. Universitas Diponegoro (UNDIP)
4. Universitas Gajah Mada (UGM)
5. Politeknik Bandung
WHyPGen will further develop program/activities that can improve the existing curricula.
Furthermore, WHyPGen Project also in the process of collaboration with Technical Education and Development Center for the mechanical, electrical and industrial known as P4TKBMTI. It is an educational institution owned by the Ministry for Education and Cultural of Republic of Indonesia. It provides training for teachers in order to improve their knowledge and skill. The trainings are specially designed for vocational school teachers. P4TKBMTI also has the role in developing and improving the curricula for engineering school (in the level of senior high school).
WHyPGen Project has provided Training of Trainer (ToT) and On the Job Training (OJT) for Technical Education and Development Center for the mechanical, electrical and Industrial (known as P4TKBMTI). The program will continue to the development of training module for the vocational school teachers. Furthermore, P4TKBMTI has included training on wind power technology as one of the training curricula in their institution. It has been socialized on xxx 2014 in which WHyPGen Project has become one of the resources persons.

4
0
WHyPGen Project had initiated the establishment of Indonesia Wind Association (IWA) through meeting and FGD. IWA was softly launched through declaration at the EBTKE Connex on 4-6 June 2014. EBTKE Connex is an annual event of seminar and exhibition that held by the Directorate General of New Energy, Renewables and Energy Conservation (DJEBTKE), Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR). For the next step, the project will facilitate and support the legal aspect of the IWA establishment. Afterward, the project will collaborate with IWA to conduct the related activities in promoting the wind energy in the country, including in advocating the required policies to the MEMR and other related government agencies.

description.narrative: Improved local wind energy system (including WHyPGen) capacity
A fully established and operational wind energy clearing house by Year 2

comment.narrative: Year 2

In 2014 the project had supported the required information and data on the wind energy in Indonesia to support establishment of RE Clearing House by MEMR. WHyPGen will continue to provide support on the activities.
Currently MEMR is setting up the required rooms, hardware and software. Based on the discussion with MEMR, WHyPGen Project will be asked to provide all the related information on wind energy project to support the clearing house, i.e wind potential data, list of available technology supplier, local manufacturer, and other supporting documents. Currently, with the data from WHyPGen submitted on Feb 2014, MEMR, with support from ESP3 (program from the Danish government) had developed wind potential map in a meso scale. However, the wind map was limited only to the Sumatera Island, some parts of Java and Sulawesi island. WHyPGen Project will develop Indonesia wind map in micro scale.

Strengthening Access to Justice in Indonesia

description.narrative: Strengthening Access to Justice in Indonesia (SAJI)
first-order administrative division
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative:
Output 1 Baseline 1.2: The first “Gap Analysis” study conducted by BAPPENAS and supported by UNDP at the end of 2010 showed some serious discrepancies between the National Strategy and the annual work plans and budget allocations of key government institutions
Baseline 1.3: The 3 targeted provinces did not incorporate all of SAJI’s NSA2J focus areas (i.e. legal aid, PCMs, and informal justice) into their government work plans and budgets for 2014.
Baseline 1.4: Through campaign activities in 2014, at least 450,000 Aceh people get exposed to information on availability of customary justice services in Aceh.
Output 2 Baseline 2.1: In order to extend access to the poor and marginalized, SMS Gateway software (GILI SMS) was installed at the PCM Unit of the Office of the Ombudsman in Bener Meriah, Aceh
Baseline 2.2:
In 2014, an additional 5 PCMs were established, bringing the total number of PCMs supported by the project in three pilot districts to 14 (from 9)
Baseline 2.3: In 2014, 320 out of 343 (95%) lodged complaints responded to through a referral system amongst different subnational agencies/institutions (reference) in 9 pilot PCMs.
A breakdown of the total # of lodged complaints responded to per district is as follows:  Bener Meriah: 84 complaints received with 81 successfully responded to (91%);  Palangkaraya: 19 complaints received with 19 successfully responded to (100%); and  Palu: 240 complaints received with 220successfully responded to (96%)
Baseline 2.4: Other than KPK, which is high on the public profile, the civil society, media, and the public at large (particularly in the provinces) lack of understanding of the exact processes, potentials, and appeal mechanisms of the government PCMs; and as such are not utilizing the PCMs effectively Based on PCM assessment in 2014, 87 % complaints in PCM Bener Meriah have responded. 100% in PCM Palangkaraya and 94% in PCM Palu
Baseline 2.5: In 2014, 9 PCMs in 3 pilot districts produced a

- Concept for an integrated public complaint mechanism (i.e. all provincial-level complaints handled by one online system) is proposed for three SAJI provincial target
- 97% lodged complaints responded through a referral system among different state agencies/institutions

278 provincial and district women parliamentarians (216 new MPs and 62 incumbents) were trained for their basic capacity in parliament.
40 National (32 new MPs and 8 incumbents) and 15 Regional (8 new MPs and 7 incumbents) women parliamentarians were trained for their basic capacity in parliament.
6 (six) modules of basic capacity building for women parliamentary at all level are developed. 1) Gender and Parliament 2) Legislation 3) Budgeting 4) Oversight 5) Decentralization and DPRD 6) Communication Skill
Based on the results of pre- and post- tests undertaken by the participants, across-the-board there has been a 44.6 percent increase in knowledge on the six modules following women MPs in DPRD and 45.5 percent women MPs in DPD-DPR RI. In the second quarter of implementing period project has delivered advanced capacity building with total 55 parallel classes that participated by 92 women MPs from four provinces of project areas (Gorontalo, Yogyakarta, Lampung and Kalimantan Tengah provinces). Within the implementation period project also conducted the measurement of increase capacity by using pre and post questioner. In overall there is 49.4 % increased capacity of participant as the result of pre-post test. Trending Topics In Gorontalo Province, Communication and Oversight topics are most interested one with 80% trend of participant’s involvement and in Yogyakarta communication and Integrity had 40 % trend. Meanwhile constituent relation is the lowest trend, which’s in average each participant had participated in four classes/topics. Knowledge Gained (Gorontalo), result of knowledge gained: with an average of 72.5%, and the highest change recorded by Legislation (90%) and follow by communication (85%), budgeting (79%), integrity (63%), constituent relation (62%), and oversight (56%). (Yogyakarta), result of knowledge gained: with an average of 52%, and the highest change recorded by Oversight (74 %) and follow by integrity (59%), constituent

description.narrative: Strengthening Innovative Partnerships for Development Cooperation (SIP-DC). The project will support the Government of Indonesia (GoI) in moving forward from the paradigm of donor-recipient relationships to partnerships for development effectiveness.
Strengthening Innovative Partnership for Development Cooperation (SIP DC)
capital of a political entity

1)availability of partnership strategies and mechanism for engagement with different types of development partners under various cooperation frameworks
2) availability of international cooperation frameworks between GOI and international partners under South-South, North-South, and triangular Cooperation modalities,
3) extent to which there are effective capacity development programmes in place for stakeholders involved in supporting the development cooperation framework,
4) adequate knowledge management system using integrated mechanism to capture various best practice and lessons learned on development issues

comment.narrative:
1. Strategy exists for partnership with bilateral and multilateral partners under the Aid Effectiveness Framework (Jakarta Commitment),
2 No comprehensive partnership strategy on South-South and North-South and Triangular Cooperation under the framework of aid effectiveness,
3. Capacity of some stakeholders involved in the development cooperation process is very limited,
4. development cooperation knowledge management system has not been established.

- Strategy for Indonesia’s role in international development forum and consolidated mechanism for partnership with UN agencies in project fully developed - Dialogue forum and capacity institution to improve capacity established - Knowledge management system fully established to facilitate the lesson learned from cross cutting issues and multi stakeholder involvement - Knowledge management system embedded in government structure

- Indonesia's strategy on international development cooperation stated in the Country's 2015-2019 Medium Term Development Plan - 2016-2020 UNPDF (UNDAF) and CPD finalised through consultative process with the government counterpart - Multistakeholders on South-South and Triangular Cooperation conducted, chaired by the Bappenas - Knowledge Management system is now embedded under one of directorate in Bappenas

description.narrative: SPARC project with support from GEF/Special Climate Change Fund (GEF/SCCF) funding will focus on strengthening and developing climate resilient institutions and rural communities around livelihoods, food and water security.
first-order administrative division

Outputs 1) A multi stakeholder dialogue on climate change has been established and institutionalized at provincial and district level 1.1 Establishment and institutionalization of multistakeholders dialogue on climate at provincial and district level 1.2 Number of multistakeholders capacitated to address climate change adaptation 1.3 Level of local policies at provincial and district government have integrated programmes on climate change adaptation and made necessary budget allocations to priority adaptation actions.

description.narrative: To enable the NTT province to strengthen climate resilience of its rural Communities to improve livelihood, food, and water security.
Annual Provincial and District government Work Plans and budgets approved by provincial and district parliaments that include specific reference to adaptation actions [refer to AMAT 1.1.1.1]

comment.narrative: Climate change is not integrated in provincial budgets and district budgets. The provincial Medium term development plan does not include any reference to climate change
budget allocation for adaptation actions in the Provincial Annual Work Plan and in the Annual Work Plans of at least three districts from 2014 onward.

The Project Objective has been partially achieved supported by following important building blocks that has been put in place to enable mainstreaming CCA in development planning and budgeting of NTT province and pilot districts by the end of the project:
- Inclusion of climate change adaptation as one of priority issues in NTT Provincial Medium Term Development Plan 2013-2019 (Regional Regulation No.1/2014) has established a legal basis for planning and budget allocation for CCA in provincial, district to village level.
- A village level Climate vulnerability and risk map for NTT province has been adopted by provincial and district development planning agency (Bappeda) as one of development planning references to inform locations and designing adaptation programme. The map has been distributed by provincial Bappeda to all districts in NTT province.
- The project provided in depth technical assistance to related sectors in provincial and district governments such as agency of Agriculture, Food Security, Meteorology, Environment, Public Work, and Bappeda in planning CCA programme for 2015 and 2016 work plan.
As a result, CCA-related activities such as water pond construction, rehabilitation of irrigation system, and improvement of rice variety have been included and budgeted in the 2015 work plan of the following sectoral government agencies in three district and provinces: Agency of Agriculture and Plantation, Food Security, the Forest Service, Department of Agriculture and Horticulture, Department of Public Works, Environment, the Regional Disaster Management, Office of Cooperative and Small and Medium Enterprises, Maritime Affairs and Fisheries.
In the rest of the project lifecycle, these activities need to be monitored and their effectiveness validated in terms of their relevance to identified climate risks and vulnerability in targeted locations, to differentiate the CCA with Business-As-Usual development activities.

description.narrative: Institutional capacity developed to integrate climate resilience in sustainable development at provincial and district level
disaggregated by gender, number of trained people mandated to support climate resilient planning

comment.narrative: no trained people mandated
at least 100 trained people are mandated to support climate resilient planning

During this reporting period, a total of 229 individuals (189 male and 40 female) have been engaged various capacity building trainings, including the following:
- Training on CCA action plan and institutional work plan formulation targeting the following agencies from three district and Province: Bappeda, Public Work, Environment, Agriculture and Plantation, Food Security, Extension, Food Crop, Forestry, Fishery and Coastal, BPTP, UNDANA University, Cooperative and small scale business (34 male, 14 female);
- Training of Trainers on Climate Field School for district agencies and agricultural extension workers of the project pilot districts (17 male, 2 female). Provincial agencies and UNDANA were invited as the resource agencies.
- Technical training for village facilitators, extension workers in three pilot Districts (92 male, 16 female). This training focused on developing skill of field facilitators in advocating for integrating CCA activities in villages, sub district and districts development work plan.
- Training for local journalists on the climate change issues, its impacts on development and rural communities; and how to communicate it for public (46 male, 8 female). The trainer was an eminent environmental journalist from Kompas, a national newspaper.
In addition to these trainings, the SPARC project initiated institutional support in the area of data management that contribute to the overall institutional capacity for integrating climate resilience in sub-national development planning. Through SPARC support, Bappeda and Stats Agency developed an online meta data system called “NTT Satu Data (NTT One Data)” which uses not just data from the Stats Dept, but also data collected through the SPARC-led vulnerability assessment and village socioeconomic assessment. It is expected to complement SIDIK (System Informasi Data Index Vulnerability) which is hosted at MoEF and contains a range of information including site-specific vulnerability and adaptation options. The information in NTT Satu Data and SIDIK is expected to contribute to an improved decision making and development planning at all levels.
-

description.narrative: number and type of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to minimize exposure to climate variability (describe number and time) [refer to AMAT 2.2.1]

comment.narrative: no systematic institutional capacity development for adaptation is ongoing
At least 5 institutes have strengthened their systems, programmes and human resources to better address climate variability

Based on the identified climate risks and required CCA actions, the project focused on the following institutions those have authority and responsibility for implementing CCA actions in provincial and district level: Bappeda, BMKG, BPTP, Regional disaster management agency, Public Work, Environment agency, Agriculture, Plantation and Livestock agency, Food Security agency, Forestry agency and Fishery agency.
In this reporting period, the project has provide technical assistance to the planner staff of above institutions to integrate CCA in the annual work plan for 2016 by using the climate risk and vulnerability map.

description.narrative: number and type of provincial and district level policies and programmes which have been adjusted / issued to address climate change resilience

comment.narrative: No integration of climate resilience in provincial and district policies and programmes
climate change resilience has been integrated in at least NTTâ€™s Medium Term Development Plan 2014-2018, and policies and programmes on agriculture and water

This indicator was achieved during the current reporting period.
NTT’s Medium Term Development Plan (RPJMD) 2013-2018 is based on Regional Regulation No. 1 of 2014 and mentions specifically that CC mitigation and adaptation as one of strategic issues that the province has to consider. In particular, they are referenced under Mission #5: Accelerate the development of infrastructure based on spatial allocation and environmental considerations. Priority: Program to establish an information and communication system to improve the resilience of communities to climate change. Indicators: 1) Total forest that can be managed by communities as part of climate mitigation and adaptation; and 2) Plan for responses to disasters and climate change starting at the village level.
In addition, Governor regulation No.29/2014 on Government Work Plan 2014 (RKPD 2014) has stated Priority Programme on CC mitigation and adaptation with targets: 23% of total forest area managed by communities and 22 districts have developed disaster and climate change action plan.

description.narrative: Livelihoods of vulnerable rural communities strengthened in a changing climate
climate risk reduction activities introduced at local level (list type and scope) [refer to AMAT 2.2.1.1]

comment.narrative: no climate risk reduction and awareness activities are introduced at local level;
At least 5 types of climate risk reduction measures have been introduced in the three target districts, of which at least three measures are specifically targeting women

Climate risk reduction measures have been implemented during this reporting period. In order to facilitate the community proposal formulation and grant disbursement processes, legal entities called Kemas ProKlim (“Community Group for Climate Programme”) were established, through support of the project team and NGO partners, in each of the target villages. One Kemas ProKlim consists of several primary community groups in a village and carry out various CCA activities. Kemas ProKlim has board at village level as well as administrative personnel that is responsible for managing grants and implementation of CCA activities. Standard operating Procedure for Kemas ProKlim operation has been developed including internal control framework for fund disbursement.
In this reporting period, nine Kemas ProKlim (from nine villages – three villages per a pilot district) have developed CCA proposals and fund have been disbursed. In total, the nine Kemas Proklim consists of 64 community groups with 64 CCA activities related to food, water and livelihoods resilience covered in nine proposals. Additionally, 12 villages (four in each pilot district) are in process of establishing a Kemas ProKlim and in developing a CCA proposal facilitated by SPARC District coordinator, local government and NGO partner.
The approved resilience building activities that are currently financed by the project include the following:
- Three Kemas ProKlim in Manggarai District focus on crop diversification to gain household income (women activities), irrigation canal rehabilitation for rice fields production; improving crop resistant variety and planting system, pipeline installation for drinking water supply, land rehabilitation in landslides prone area, mattresses production (household activities for women group) and cattle fattening.
- In Sumba Timur district, three Kemas ProKlim focus on improving rice field production (good practices, resistant variety), annual crop diversification, annual crop seedling for conservation of water catchment area and productive use, crop diversification, fish production, clean water supply.
- In Sabu Raijua district, three Kemas Proklim implement CCA activities in improvement of clean water supply, crop diversification, dry land rice production, maize production and water catchment conservation.

description.narrative: % of households with a lower perception of vulnerability to climate risks due to new adaptation measures being introduced and applied, disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative: currently, the majority of households regard themselves as highly vulnerability to climate risks
at least 75% of the households that have implemented adaptation measures regard themselves less vulnerable to climate change related risks as a result

The implementation of CCA activities are targeting impact at household level, rather than village level. Based on the CCA proposals of Kemas Proklim, SPARC project team is currently developing monitoring tool to measure baseline situation of the participating households in CCA activities.
Three short movies describing the baseline situation in 9 pioneering villages in 3 pilot districts have been developed for advocacy and monitoring:

title.narrative: Data Innovation for Enhanced Public Services Delivery

description.narrative: The overarching objective is that the Government of Indonesia and target sub-national governments have access to and use quality real-time "big data" to inform policy making, planning and budgeting.

title.narrative: Data Innovation for enhanced public service delivery
Data Innovation for Enhanced Public Services Delivery
Data Innovation for Enhanced Public Services Delivery
Data Innovation for Enhanced Public Services Delivery

description.narrative: The activity will lead to better service delivery through more effective feedback loops between citizens and governments. Capacity of local authorities to understand and use data to gather new insights will be developed.
Other General Services - support to civil society

- Feasibility studies that summarise the results of assessments of the potential of a dataset to yield insights on a topic of interest.
- Findings reports that present detailed results of analysis performed in the course of conducting a research project.
- Methods papers that elaborate the analytical methodology developed in the course of conducting a research project.
- Big Data proof of concepts to facilitate generic tasks involved in collecting, anonymising, storing, analysing and visualising specific types of big data.
- Data systems to support partner governments, civil society organisations or DFAT programs to establish innovative interaction between stakeholders.
- Capacity building for a critical number of staff within relevant national and regional government structures, as well as DFAT program teams, to make them familiar with new approaches to data collection and analysis and quick data turnaround for feedback and management for better service delivery.

comment.narrative:
1. Exploration and research to get a better, contextual understanding of the issues and scan the external environment for relevant innovations in other contexts or countries.
2. Advanced data analytics conducted to gather new insights with an aim is to build capacity over time of local authorities to conduct this type of analysis independently.
3. DFAT, PLJ and subnational authorities will jointly pursue opportunities to explore the use of big data for real time monitoring.
4. Rapid prototyping: based on the results of the above, a number of interventions will be tested on a portfolio basis to gather early feedback from stakeholders and identify upfront potential implementation risks.

description.narrative: Judiciary Oversight Mechanism

Indicators : 1.1) Level of satisfaction of users with services of SUSTAIN counterpart courts and extent to which these courts implement recommendations from survey results 1.2) % of complaints responded to by Supervisory Body of Supreme Court (BAWAS) and (b) % of complaints responded to by pilot courts 1.3) (a) % of Supreme Court justices, Courts of General Jurisdictions Judges, Administrative Court (TUN) Judges, and Special Court Judges that submit their wealth reports to KPK;and (b) the extent to which this feeds into decision-making including sanctions for non-compliers

comment.narrative:
Baselines: 1.1). TBD in 2016. Currently, the Indonesia Center for Law and Policy Studies (PSHK) manages a survey which measures the level of satisfaction of users with UNDP and non-UNDP supported courts. Due to financial problems, this CSO is unable to continue undertaking this survey. The project will undertake this survey, but the survey instruments may be changed 1.2) 55.1% of complaints responded to by the Supervisory Body of the Supreme Court (meaning, of the 1,824 complaints letters received, 1,005 complainants were informed in writing how their complaint was addressed), and 28.57% (1 out of 3.5) of complaints responded to by pilot courts
1.3) Over the last 5 yrs (2010-2014), there has been a steady increase in the number of Supreme Court Justices submitting their wealth reports from 86.25% (2010) to 91.55% (2014). This is likewise true of the Military Courts, with the number of Military Court Judges submitting wealth reports increasing from 87.5% (2010) to 93.75% (2014).

1.1). UNDP will review survey instruments of the Indonesia Centre for Law and Policy Studies (PSHK), make any adjustments to the survey, and identify financing and institutional arrangements to ensure the survey is continued beyond the life of the project 1.2) (a) 60% complaints are responded to by BAWAS; and (b) 40%complaints responded to by pilot courts. 1.3). Supreme Court Justices: 93.24%; General Court Judges: 91.06%; TUN Judges: 78.19%; (b) Establish a system in the Supreme Court to ensure better compliance, including through sanctions, to be tested initially in the pilot courts.

Even though the State Administration Institute (Lembaga Administrasi Negara/LAN) and PT TUV consider the capacity of the Training Centre to be high (in 2012, LAN awarded the Centre its highest accreditation of A [valid for five years]; whilst PT TUV has certified the Centre provides training and education in line with international standards), the absence of TNA and post-training evaluation, demonstrate the Centre’s capacity can be further strengthened. description.narrative: Human Resource and organization
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

3.1) Extent to which human resource management (HRM) system integrated with Supreme Court Information System (SIMARI), and used for performance based management
3.2).Extent to which new HRM system results in improvements in individual and institutional performance

comment.narrative:
3.1). Currently, there has been an established Personnel Information Management System (SIMPEG) at First Instance and Appellate courts level. The Supreme Court’ plan to integrate this with - Supreme Court Information System (SIMARI) as one centralised repository database is a work in progress. The Supreme Court is progressively providing technical assistance to First Instance and Appellate courts to be able to synchronise its data into SIMARI and to utilize it to inform decisions and policy making. SIMPEG utilizes Application Programming Interface to connect four Appellate and First Instance court jurisdiction’ databases. API SIMARI includes various features such as SKP (Sasaran Kerja Pegawai)- Online Employee Targets, Online Timesheet, Baperjakat Information System, Multi Reporting System, etc.
3.2). N/A
3.1) Recommendations developed to strengthen performance based HRM system based on assessment of current system 3.2) N/A

description.narrative: Enhanced Case Managment
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

4.1). (i) The extent to which CTS/SIPP Road Map in target courts nationwide have been completed and (ii) the extent to which it increased case handling; (a) Progressive increase of clearance rate of target courts nationwide (pilot courts, TUN and from 2018 onwards Military Courts(b) Progressive increase of the target courts performance indicator 4.2) .The extent the administrative, military and religious courts (first instance and appellate) electronic case management system have been integrated into the Supreme Court’s wider information system SIMARI Terintegrasi (Sistem Informasi Mahkamah Agung Republik Indonesia –Terintegrasi). 4.3). Standard operating procedures on how to process cases involving vulnerable groups such as women and children, including rehabilitation and reintegration programmes are in place and implemented. 4.4) Tax decision is available and accessible to the public with consideration of confidentiality and classified information

comment.narrative:
4.1). Since beginning of 2012, Case Tracking System began to be introduced and implemented in all District Courts in Indonesia. In August 2013, 350 lower courts have been utilizing CTS. The newest version of CTS, (Version 3) was launched and introduced to all lower courts and 30 high courts in Indonesia. It has been implemented in more than 70 lower courts. (http://pn-blitar.go.id/berita-terbaru/1309-memastikan-keadilan-melalui-otomatisasi) Until the end of 2013 case management system has been implemented in all court jurisdictions. General Courts use SIPP/CTS, Religious Court use Sistem Informasi Administrasi Perkara Peradilan Agama Plus (SIADPA PLUS), TUN use Sistem Informasi Administrasi Perkara Tata Usaha Negara (SIADTUN) and Military Courts use Sistem Informasi Perkara Peradilan Militer (SIADMIL) (LTMARI 2013 p.15) Per May 2015, from the Supreme Court’s Case Tracking System (CTS) database (courts of general jurisdictions) there are 6365 cases (6-12 months) and 8160 cases (more than 12 months). This figure may not be an actual number (weakness of CTS on data compliance). (http://sipp-ma.mahkamahagung.go.id/index.php). According to Supreme Court Chief of Justice Decree No 214/KMA/SK/XII/2014 dated 31 December 2014, effective 1 January 2015: maximum 8 months case handling at the Supreme Court level; Supreme Court Circular No 2 of 2014 dated 13 March 2014 applied for court of first instance (5 months) while appellate courts (3 months) (2015:12). Since 2014 the CTS (version 3) has been applied/operational at all first instance and appellate courts (general jurisdictions (2015:234). In 2014 there are 347 courts of first instance and 30 appellate courts (http://www.badilum.info/index.php/article/24/78).
4.2) There has yet to be a unified electronic case management system. Ideally those systems will be integrated into SIMARI -Terintegrasi (Sistem Informasi Mahkamah Agung Republik Indonesia –Terintegrasi). Currently, the CTS (SIPP) only applies to courts of

4.1). (i) 20% of CTS/SIPP Road Map is successfully implemented and Initial step to introduce SIPP to 28 TUN and TBD number of Military Courts is completed (ii) (a) 70-80% clearance rate of 14 pilot courts; (b) 60-70% court performance indicator of 14 pilot courts
4.2) First step of administrative and military court case management system to SIMARI is completed 4.3). Recommendations on alternative sanctions for children and petty crimes are in place and introduced to relevant stakeholders. 4.4 At least 1 workshop is conducted with Tax Court and Pusintek to develop regulatory framework for the case management system in tax court
